message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest adhesive capsulitis, also known as frozen shoulder, as there is a decrease in both active and passive range of motion of the left shoulder and significant pain. The normal rotator cuff strength and normal radiographs rule out rotator cuff injury and glenohumeral arthritis. The absence of neck pain, arm/hand weakness, numbness, or paresthesias makes degenerative cervical spine disease less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of pain at extremes of range of motion and difficulty with activities of daily living suggest adhesive capsulitis or frozen shoulder. Other options such as degenerative cervical spine disease, rotator cuff injury, and glenohumeral arthritis would have different findings on physical examination or radiographs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms - insidious onset of shoulder pain at extremes of range of motion, difficulty with activities of daily living, and decreased range of motion with significant pain - suggest adhesive capsulitis, also known as frozen shoulder. None of the other options fit with the symptoms provided. X-rays may be normal in adhesive capsulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest adhesive capsulitis, commonly known as frozen shoulder, which is characterized by difficulty with movements at the end of the range of motion and is often associated with diabetes mellitus. The normal rotator cuff strength and normal radiographs help rule out rotator cuff injury and glenohumeral arthritis. Degenerative cervical spine disease may cause neck pain and radiating symptoms, but not the specific shoulder pain and limitation of motion described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially difficulty with shoulder range of motion, suggest adhesive capsulitis. The normal rotator cuff strength eliminates rotator cuff injury as a possibility. The lack of neck pain and history of shoulder trauma make degenerative cervical spine disease unlikely. Glenohumeral arthritis typically presents with pain and decreased range of motion in multiple planes of movement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of insidious onset of pain with limited range of motion suggest adhesive capsulitis, also known as frozen shoulder. The absence of trauma and normal rotator cuff strength make rotator cuff injury less likely. Degenerative cervical spine disease and glenohumeral arthritis may also cause shoulder pain but typically present differently.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pattern of pain and limited range of motion without rotator cuff weakness or imaging abnormalities suggests adhesive capsulitis, also known as frozen shoulder. Degenerative cervical spine disease would present with neck pain, arm/hand weakness, and imaging abnormalities. Rotator cuff injury would present with weakness and imaging abnormalities. Glenohumeral arthritis would present with pain and imaging abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of insidious onset of left shoulder pain, difficulty sleeping on the affected side, and difficulty with daily activities. These symptoms are indicative of adhesive capsulitis (also known as frozen shoulder). Additionally, the normal rotator cuff strength and normal radiographs rule out rotator cuff injury and glenohumeral arthritis. Degenerative cervical spine disease would present with neck pain and possibly arm/hand weakness, which the patient denies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question stem are consistent with adhesive capsulitis, also known as frozen shoulder. This condition is characterized by pain and restricted range of motion in the shoulder joint, often without a clear underlying cause. The lack of visible pathology on radiographs also supports this diagnosis over other options such as rotator cuff injury or arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including limited range of motion and pain at the extremes of range of motion, suggest adhesive capsulitis or frozen shoulder. The absence of arm/hand weakness, numbness, or paresthesias rules out degenerative cervical spine disease. Normal rotator cuff strength and radiographs rule out rotator cuff injury and glenohumeral arthritis.
